Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversification in the Deep-Sea and the Evolution of Fangs, Bioluminescence, Hermaphroditism, and Marine Habitat Transitions
Award.AbstractNarration:
All animals that have evolved in the deep sea are under similar selective pressures as a result of the environment (e.g., little to no sunlight, high atmospheric pressure). This extreme habitat has led to massive convergence in animal morphology and behavior across deep-sea organisms, including bioluminescence, enlarged fangs and gaping mouths. In this project, the investigators will build phylogenies, model the evolution of deep-sea adaptations and uncover the links between these adaptations and diversification rates in three major clades of fishes. This study integrates phylogenetic relationships based on genetic and morphological data, comparative morphology, ecology, and evolutionary biology in an effort to broaden our understanding of fishes that have evolved, thrived, and diversified in the deep sea.

This research will increase our understanding of a diverse array of deep-sea evolutionary adaptations, including bioluminescent structures that are used for predation, defense, species recognition, and sexual selection. These novel morphologies and behaviors have never before been studied within the context of a robust evolutionary framework based on molecular and morphological data. The resulting hypotheses will include a temporal component based on the fossil record that will allow us to explore, for the first time, whether these specializations are having potential effects on speciation in the deep sea. This project will support the training of postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in marine biology, systematics, and evolutionary biology at the University of Kansas and American Museum of Natural History. Findings from this work will continue to augment a new bioluminescence exhibit created and curated by PI Sparks and co-PI Smith (Creatures of Light).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Of the nearly 33,000 valid species of ray-finned fishes, more than 5,000 inhabit the deep sea at depths below 200 meters. All fishes that evolved in the deep sea are under similar selective pressures as a result of the environmental extremes (e.g., little to no penetrable sunlight, high atmospheric pressure); this is hypothesized to have led to a wide range of convergent morphologies and behaviors. Bioluminescent organs and photophores, tubular/enlarged eyes, hermaphroditism, and large mouths with dagger-like teeth have independently evolved in numerous deep-sea fishes. This multidisciplinary project investigated evolutionary patterns and processes in three of the most species-rich, deep-sea, lineages of fishes: lizardfishes and allies, lanternfishes and allies, and dragonfishes and allies. In total, these three groups encompass over 1,000 species and over twenty percent of all vertebrate deep-sea biodiversity. 

We produced hypotheses of evolutionary relationships for lanternfishes, dragonfishes, and lizardfishes that included newly collected genome-scale molecular data (ultraconserved elements, protein-coding gene fragments). We produced the most taxonomically comprehensive and data-rich hypotheses of evolutionary relationships ever for the lizardfishes, lanternfishes, and dragonfishes which had a significant impact on our knowledge of these fishes and led to revised classifications. These phylogenetic reconstructions served as frameworks for studying character evolution, divergence times, and diversification within and among these lineages. 

Our work identified that bioluminescence has been critical to the evolution of deep-sea animals. Investigations into the evolution of bioluminescence across ray-finned fishes identified 27 independent evolutions of bioluminescence in marine fishes. We found that fishes that use bioluminescence for communication have increased rates of speciation compared to lineages that use bioluminescence predominantly for camouflage. The results from our studies are significant and represent a remarkable increase in our understanding of how many times bioluminescence has evolved in vertebrates and its impact on the diversification of marine animals that use light for communication. Our comparative anatomical work on bioluminescent systems identified the first known bioluminescent organ derived from liver tissue.

We found that biofluorescent emissions are widespread throughout ray-finned fishes and have evolved in at least 50 families of marine fishes. This significant result has had a transformative impact on the study of visualization systems in ray-finned and cartilaginous fishes. As a follow up to this work, we identified that biofluorescence can be visualized in some lineages of cartilaginous fishes (swell sharks). This works highlights the potential importance of biofluorescence in marine animal behavior and biology.

We explored the evolution of and variation of venom within venomous fishes. We inferred the first multi-locus, ordinal-level phylogenetic analysis of cartilaginous and ray-finned fishes in a single analysis that hypothesizes 18 independent evolutions of venom in aquatic vertebrates. We inferred that among approximately 2386-2962 extant venomous fishes, envenomed structures have evolved four times in cartilaginous fishes, once in eels, once in catfishes, and 12 times in spiny-rayed fishes. From our anatomical studies and phylogenetic reconstruction, we show that dorsal spines are the most common envenomed structures (95% of venomous fish species and 15 independent evolutions).

Our work on fluorescence led to the discovery of a new visualization technique for imaging and studying the anatomy of vertebrates. This technique involves using fluorescence to improve imaging of bones and other anatomical structures and included the description of a new gelatin-like approach for suspending specimens in place during three-dimensional imaging.

Broader Impacts

Over the course of the five years six undergraduate students, five graduate students, and two postdocs, were trained at St. Cloud State University and the University of Kansas. These trainees included six female scientists (three undergraduate, three graduate students) and two students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields (one undergraduate and one graduate student). Results from the work on the evolution, diversification, and character evolution of deep-sea adaptations were disseminated at local and international scientific conferences by the PIs and students, published in peer-review journals, and disseminated by the PIs in a freely available audio podcast (The Fishmongers). Results were also incorporated in a traveling museum exhibit, Creatures of Light, that has been on exhibit over the course of the grant at numerous museums including the American Museum of Natural History, The Field Museum, The Denver Museum of Nature and Science, and the Cleveland Museum of Natural History. Data from all published studies are open and available to the public (see respective published products for further information on accessing data). The findings from our studies were widely disseminated to the public through popular press articles based on the findings from our work. The results of our work based on this award were featured by organizations such as CNN, Fox News, BBC, New York Times, National Geographic, Science, Nature, LA Times, The Washington Post, Scientific American, Newsweek, Slate, and Wired.
